displayed_text: Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And then no pain. So, you’re the asymptomatic person Patient: Okay. Gotch ya. Doctor: and like uh, I got cancer, what, oh, perfect Provenge candidate. But you could get there again once like so he said can I get Provenge after Xofigo. Sure, if your pain was controlled. Even if your PSA wasn’t so low, having discomfort puts you in a different group. It just means your cancer is not behaving and having it go up on treatment is different than you not on anything and having it go up Patient: Okay. Doctor: and at this moment it’s not behaving. Patient: That’s why I’m always like at that time when I was low or no pain and that’s why he was thinking that’s what we… Doctor: Yeah, Yes, that would have been. Yeah. Patient: Okay. I understand that now. Doctor: So, like back then would have been or if we get you stable and kind of quiet and good we could always redo it, Patient: We can still. Okay. Okay. Doctor: Right. So, it’s not off the table forever. It’s just at this moment it’s not. Patient: At this moment, I understand that, okay.

Patient: Well I mean it’s- Doctor: It’s not always like that but it’s possible. Patient: No. No. No. It’s better to know what you’re dealing with than not. What about the treatment side of it in Europe? I mean what do they do once, let’s say you’re a candidate. Then they, do they attach to the uh to the antibody? Doctor: Well, so it’s not an antibody. Patient: Oh. Its an enzyme, enzyme.. Doctor: It’s a, uh, it’s a little very tiny little piece of just a little chemical. Patient: Oh. Doctor: That has enough specificity that it’s a glue to the antibody. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And uh so what they usually do is uh you go there. They do screening tests including an imaging test. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh they give you a treatment. At least my experience is then they keep you for a little bit and image you maybe once or twice after to look at how much your cancer took up the material.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Because you’re you’re just not going to be able to be strong enough. Other than that - Patient: Yeah. But strong enough now. Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: But I mean from a fact that I guess I’m looking for the future Doctor: Of course, Patient: though too and this question that - Doctor: remember this is a marathon race. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: You know we can’t sprint from thing to thing you’ll be exhausted – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - and we won’t go anywhere. Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: That’s an immunotherapy? Doctor: No that’s a it’s a PARP inhibitor which is known to produce really good responses with this medication, with the BRCA mutant prostate cancer. Okay? Patient: Including BRCA2? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s the one we had the article about. Doctor: Yeah, so I think you know that is sort of the somewhat well paved route. Okay because it’s known that the response rates are likely to be pretty good. The other way is -- Patient: Would I continue on the Xtandi in that case or not? Family Member: Okay but she said there’s a third choice. Patient: Just a second, just a second, just a second I’m digesting this. Family Member: Sorry. Patient: Thank you. Ah… Doctor: I know it’s a lot of things to go through.

Healthcare Professional: Do we have to take for that too? Patient: So you want me to have her set up for one week from today? Doctor: Yeah, next week. Patient: Okay, alrighty. Doctor: Yep, yep and if I don’t need you to come we’ll call you and let you know… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …that you know, everything’s fine you don’t need to come or whatever. Patient: Alright then no problem. Doctor: Alright?

Family Member: Yes. Doctor: And your cancer, really, is not showing any major activity, so. Family Member: Great. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Uh, uh, the PSA looks normal. Doctor: Well, it’s forty-three, though. Patient: Right. Doctor: That’s not a whole lot, uh, for change. And your scans have not shown any major change. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know? The ones she did in, uh, end of November or December, whenever you saw her last. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, so based on that, I wouldn’t change anything. I think you should stick with, uh, the Lupron should be continued and the bone medication. Are they doing both of those?

Patient: Well, I don’t think it was so much carrying boxes because my kids and my wife wouldn’t let me carry weight. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: But you did. Patient: But it was, no but it was never a heavy weight. It was just, yeah, I did do a lot of up and down the stairs. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Steps. Patient: And I noticed you know like the first day that Doctor: Right. Family Member: Could that trigger? Doctor: Of course. Hey my other guy, you know what he did? He wasn’t going up and down the stairs. He was just working under the tree putting his little village together. Up and down, up and down; he’s got the same symptom as you. So I think – Patient: So this isn’t something that if I give it total rest for - Doctor: Oh I’m sure that it will get better if you give it total rest. But it doesn’t change this discussion that I see new areas of cancer in your bone. Whether that’s causing pain is slightly different because I’m assuming it may. But it could be worsened because you were just moving. Family Member: Hum. So they’ll radiate?

Patient: I’m normal? Doctor: At least on your electrolytes, you are. And then your PSA has increased. Patient: Ah. Doctor: So last time it was 303. So 247, 303, and then today we have a measurement of 352. Patient: It’s getting worse and worse. Oh, well. Doctor: Have you ever had a bone scan before? Patient: No. Today I did. Doctor: So that was your first one ever? Patient: Uh-huh. Doctor: Okay. Okay. So because of your PSA going up, we checked scans. The bone scan tells us that, huh, you’ve got a lot of cancer in your bones. We sort of knew that from before even though we haven’t had a picture of that, and so, again, when they talk about what this looks like I have nothing to compare it to. Huh, but this is you, your body, these things here represent the cancer. So here’s your back bone, also a lot of it here in your ribs in multiple spots, a couple of areas on the skull bone that look like there’s cancer there, or one area in this, huh, your right, your left leg. Huh, huh, and then the CAT scan says, huh, that’s what we had used at the very beginning, huh, which says that basically all the areas in the bone that they saw before are still there, huh, with, huh, additional spots. Huh, and you’ve got some really small lymph nodes down in your pelvis. All that is doctor lingo for, huh, you know, you’ve had benefit from the hormone therapy, huh, but I really can’t tell you how much worse it is because these are the first real pictures since you’ve gotten started. You’re hanging in there, huh, but it would be, you know, time to change therapy. Family Member: Okay. We know. Patient: So what kind of pills can I take?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we gotta go on a different hunt. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: What you… Doctor: Well good. You’re otherwise feeling okay? You look like a million buck from the, I mean I feel like I haven’t seen you in ages because I haven’t seen you in ages. Patient: No I ain’t saw you either. (Laughs) Doctor: W____ will come in with the paperwork and then we’ll get you out of here. Patient: Okay fine. Doctor: Okay? Any questions? Patient: No. Doctor: No?

Patient: And my hydration has always been plus a little bit in there. So I think that that might be a temporary ah thing like for the last two days. Doctor: Mhmm. Okay. Patient: It could have been – and my schedule is pretty weird. Family Member: Oh yes. Doctor: Is it easing up so you can take some fluids or am I giving you fluids today? (pause) Family Member: Oh boy. Patient: No it’s – no… …it’s easy, it’s easy enough yeah… Family Member: If he thinks of it he can get it anywhere he is. Patient: Because I drink water. I like water. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: You’re gonna have to make it an effort then get in to see the nephrology folks… Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Now I get the impression he might do more than just the two that were were pressing right now. Doctor: I think that would be important for us because Patient: Yeah. Doctor: we may need to you know not treat them all and leave one so that you’re actually eligible- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -for the trial, which is a terrible thing to say. Patient: Well, I mean- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: -at least we’re going to get them all. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I mean - I don’t know. Doctor: Yeah, you just need to know where he wants to put the

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.::: strongly disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: So do we schedule the appointment today? Doctor: For coming downtown? Yeah somebody will call you once we have everything. Patient: And so we’re not scheduling it today. Doctor: Do you want to come later on this week? Tell me what day works well and how long you need to think about the consent and everything? Patient: Just coming to the midtown? Family Member: To do the tests honey. Doctor: Yeah to do the testing and to do the… Family Member: Is this the long day. Is the first day the long day? Doctor: Oh no, no that’s not treatment day. It’s just pre – all of the screening and testing will happen that day. Family Member: So what would that – that’s an echo and what else? Doctor: Yeah I think the echo and the specialized blood work that we have to send out. Family Member: So there’s just echo and blood work.

Patient: No. It seems to mirror what I was experiencing before. Doctor: Because I think between now and the six weeks that stuffs coming out of you, you decide whether, you know, if it’s looking like even week three of our six-week little holiday here, you go, yeah, you know what, this stuff’s really not getting any better. You call us. We’ll just order the MRI. Poof. Done. Family Member: He’s supposed to see Dr. V___ in a couple of weeks. Doctor: Good. Good. Patient: I think it’s July second - Doctor: Okay. Patient: - I see him. Doctor: I’m sure he’s going to be happy with your progress, but we’ll see. Again, if you see him then, and you’re like, ah, not better, hello, he can order the MRI. Family Member: Yeah. He’s been taking the Norco and stuff where before he wasn’t taking that. Doctor: How’s the rest of you? Family Member: Tired. Patient: Yeah. Sleep, sleep is a-

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Is that wrong for you or you just came in rushing? Patient: No, no, it’s usually pretty good, about one forty, one fifty at the highest. So that is a little high, yeah. Doctor: Are you taking Ondansetron? That’s for nausea. Patient: Uh occasionally, not as much as I did when I was going through radiation. Doctor: So occasionally, like once a week, once a month? Patient: Uh twice a week. Family Member: You took it last night, didn’t you when you were nauseous. Patient: Oh yeah, yeah, okay, about twice a week then. And Tums. Doctor: Okay so you take the Amlodipine once a day. Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: Baby aspirin?

Patient: Oh. Doctor: The key is you’re still – you know it’s still shrinking. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Until I get you – you could get five more, but if you beat me by getting your PSA to zero, then I’ll stop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: How’s that for a challenge? Family Member: So if it comes back today and it’s zero? Doctor: Fine. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: It’s up to you so don’t screw up it’s not me. Patient: No she’s got it wrong, but thank you. Doctor: But if you guys don’t go over, honestly they’re gonna scream at me. Patient: Okay. Okay. Okay..
